Days of Heaven directed by Terrence Malick  USA 1978 98 min.

Malick's long anticipated 5th feature,  The Tree of Life,  is scheduled to screen at Cannes , with a US release in May . Emerson College is presenting a few of his earlier films and I for one, would like to see Days of Heaven on the big screen once again.

I am  considering Penang,  a Malaysian restaurant for our group discussion afterward. Any other restaurant suggestions would be greatly  appreciated.

 Released five years after his debut feature Badlands, Malick’s second film is a decadently illustrated tragedy set among the fertile wheat fields of the Texas Panhandle in the early 20th century. When a wealthy yet stoic landowner (Shepard, in his first on-screen role) falls in love with the girlfriend (Adams) of a quick-tempered farmhand (Gere), tensions give way to greed and deception, compromising the harmony of the natural environment which fuels the aura of the film’s elegance.

“Malick’s vision of history and geography is poetic rather than factual, so too his sense of narrative lyrical rather than linear. Nothing sets him apart from his contemporaries, not to mention the succeeding generation of American directors, as much as his commitment to cinematic beauty.” – Vlada Petric, Film Quarterly

Days of Heaven is drenched in trancelike moodiness; Malick gracefully moves the camera amongst the characters of his uniquely elliptical narrative while texturing each scene with sound and image from the world that surrounds them. Nestor Almendros’ cinematography blends breathtakingly expansive images of the majestic setting with startling close-ups, earning the film its universal acclaim as a visual masterpiece. Emerson Description

Almost incontestably the most gorgeously photographed film ever made. Village Voice

It is among the most startlingly beautiful of color films. But it is not beauty for beauty's sake... The seemingly random shots have a divine order to them. Combusible Celluloid

 

Hope to see you there,

Tom
